tuv.seg: The sevenfold and threefold empowerment, And also the unsurpassable one, O Teacher—
Explain them to me in short, For the sake of mundane and supramundane accomplishments!
I will explain to you in summary The empowerment and its purpose; these sevenfold, Threefold, and unsurpassable empowerments;
And the movement in the channels and its control. In the tantras there are three types of summaries And three types of explanations , Including the precise summary, the extensive summary,
The precise explanation, and the other
Are referred to as the recitation of the tantra. The precise summary and the explanation
The extensive summary and the explanation
Are commentaries that indicate the entirety of the meaning.
They must be composed by those who have obtained supramundane knowledge,

Through these six , The tantra of the Ādibuddha called Kālacakra is perfect: Perfect through fourfold vajrayoga; Perfect through the four types of awakening; Perfect through the psycho-physical aggregates, Elements, sense bases, and six families;
Perfect through the five chapters, on the world realm and so forth;
First, there is the sevenfold empowerment
Then the threefold one in terms of the relative truth of the world;
And the fourth in terms of the ultimate truth.
The teaching of myself, the vajra holder, Concerning phenomena, is in terms of the twofold truth:
The relative truth of the world And the ultimate truth. {9} The sevenfold empowerment, O King, Consists of those of water,
The purification of body, speech, and mind,
With two each, comprise the first six empowerments; The purification of wisdom, the permission empowerment.
The other purifications are the purification of the elements and so forth:
The water empowerment is the purification of the elements ; That of the crown is the purification of the psycho-physical aggregates; That of the ribbon is the purification of the perfections;
Those of the vajra and the bell are for the great immovable bliss
And one’s uninterrupted buddha speech, respectively—
They are the purification of the sun and moon into one.
The purification of the objects and sense faculties
Is the vajra vow that remains intact.
The name empowerment is the purification of love, compassion, joy, and equanimity. That of permission is the purification for achieving buddhahood.
These seven empowerments must only be given
Next follows the vase empowerment, the secret empowerment, That called wisdom from a prajñā
Then, again, that of great prajñā,
Which is known as wisdom gained from her
The first three are, respectively, moving, moving, and vibrating,
And the supreme one is beyond vibration.
The first three empowerments are taken, respectively, As the purification of body, speech, and mind,
And the fourth is the purification of wisdom. The purification of body, speech, and mind.
The three correspond to the level of a child, adult, and elder,
And the fourth to the level of the universal ancestor.
From touching the breast of the prajñā,
There is the bliss of descending bodhicitta.
The adept empowered by the breast is the child
Because such bliss is attained from touching the breast.
From moving the vajra in the secret part for a long time,
The bliss of the further-descending bodhicitta has arisen.
The adept empowered by the secret part is the adult
Because such bliss is attained from the secret part.
From moving the vajra in the secret part for a long time,
The bliss of vibration has arisen at the tip of the vajra.
The adept empowered by the wisdom from a prajñā is the elder
Because of having realized the bliss from vibration. {20} That which has arisen from passion for the mahāmudrā
The adept empowered by the great prajñā is the universal ancestor
Because he realizes the state without vibration.
The universal ancestor should be known
As the creator of all protectors.
Being in a state without duality or movement, He is called Vajrasattva, the Great Being, and Bodhisattva,
The one bestowing liberation on yogins.
Namely, the ten signs beginning with smoke,
Which are reflections of insight, similar to the sky.
They are beyond existence and nonexistence,
Are objects verified in one’s own experience, And are entirely devoid
Of accumulations of atoms and particles. {25} They are smoke, a mirage,
A firefly, a lamp, a flame, the moon, the sun,
Darkness , digit of the moon, and the great drop—
With eyes neither closed nor open,
This reflection is seen in emptiness,
Like in a dream. Without following it,
One must constantly meditate on this reflection.
The meditation on this nonexistent reflection
Is not the meditation of yogins;
To the mind appears neither existence nor nonexistence,
Because of seeing the reflections of emptiness without having imagined them.
Just as a virgin sees in the divinatory mirror
The magical image of something unreal, So, too, the yogin sees in space
The object in the reflection is not something real
Because she sees what is empty of real entities.
Is like an illusion, a dream, or magic.
Yet, even though it does not exist,
The manifestation of a phenomenon is observed.
It is like a wish-fulfilling jewel
That fulfills the hopes of limitless beings.
In the magical image, the virgin
Sees a thief and so forth not yet seen
Having gone there, the officiants of the divination See him with their ordinary eyes.
If she sees a real form,
Why does she not see her own face?
But if she sees an unreal form,
Why does she not see a hare’s horn?
She sees neither with the eyes of others,
What is being seen has not arisen—
It is like the child of a virgin.
One must immediately perform breath control, Because body, speech, and mind
Should be arrested in the three upper and three lower channels
With regard to the channels—which are the path for
The moon, the sun, Rāhu, excrement, urine, and semen, And which correspond to the families of the elements of
Water, fire, space, earth, wind, and wisdom— The channels of body, speech, and mind are taught to be, With regard to the vital wind and downward-moving wind, respectively,
The channels of the moon, the sun, and Rāhu,
As well as those of excrement, urine, and semen.
The moon is the body of means,
The sun is the speech of insight,
The channel of excrement is the body of insight,
The channel of urine is the speech of the omnipresent.
One upward and one downward—the two channels of mind Carry Rāhu and the semen, respectively.
The mind of means is the channel of Rāhu,
And the mind of insight is the channel of semen. Upward and downward and combined with body, speech, and mind,
These channels are the six families.
As the aspects of means and the aspects of insight.
Due to strong winds above and below, Signs of death emerge in the channels of body and speech.
Birth, death, and duration Are related to the channels of Rāhu and of semen.
At the time of birth, death, and during intercourse, The channel of semen
At the moment of transit, the ascendant rises,
The middle channel carries the breath of equinox.
It lasts fifty-six and one-quarter breaths, O protector of men, Counting inhalation and exhalation as one.
In one day and night there are six hundred Seventy-five
Flow in the left and right channels.
They flow in the middle channel for three years
And three fortnights during one hundred years.
In the upper part, the left and right channels Are the moon, lalanā, and iḍā
and the sun, piṅgalā , and the other
These two have the nature of water and fire,
And are taken to hold the lotus and the jewel .
In the lower part, there are the two channels of excrement and urine, Having the nature of earth and wind.
They are the middle and left channels,
And are known to hold the disc and the sword .
In the upper and the lower part, the middle and right channel, Are those of Rāhu and semen.
They have the nature of emptiness and wisdom,
And both are known to hold vajras
The channel of excrement connects with the path of the moon,
The channel of urine with the path of the sun, And the channel of semen with the path of Rāhu.
The latter is responsible for birth, death, equinox, and intercourse.
The avadhūtī above the navel is called
The channel of the semen below is called
Sky-goer face (Skt. khagamukhā ) and conch-shell channel (Skt. śaṅkhinī
Passing through the lotuses of the navel, heart, throat, Forehead, and crown of the head, transports earth into water, water into fire,
Fire into wind, and wind into emptiness—in the mode of dissolution. Exhaling and inhaling again,
It reenters the earth element by way of production. The avadhūtī runs
And carries body, speech, and mind At the navel and the secret lotus of the jewel.
Exhaling and inhaling, It has the nature of dissolution and production, respectively. The śaṅkhinī carries the downward-moving wind
Due to the bliss of women, It carries semen;
and at the time of menstruation it carries blood.

The left and right channels above, And those carrying excrement and urine below, Refer to the factors of insight and means respectively, As do the channels of menstrual blood and semen. Carrying menstrual blood, the śaṅkhinī is called caṇḍālī
Carrying semen, it is called khagamukhā
Above, the avadhūtī is called ḍombī in women referring to menstruation;
In men it is called avadhūtī.
The five maṇḍalas, starting with consciousness,
Always flow in the left channel
The ones starting with earth, in the right channel;
The sixth , in the middle channel.
On the lotus petals at the level of the navel are,
At the time of the left and right ascendants,
Constituted by the six starting with Aries and the six starting with Taurus, The vital breath flows in the two nostrils in due order
To the base, the left, the right, above, and to the middle , Passing through one maṇḍala after the other,
Starting with earth, during each daṇḍa
One day and night have 60 nāḍikās;
They are the maṇḍalas of the body
The vital breath flows to the center of the petals and then, in due order,
Above , to the right , left , and below .
In the left nostril the elements always start with space,
And in the right with earth in reverse order.
In the left occurs formation starting with consciousness,
And in the right occurs dissolution starting with earth.
The earth is below and the wind above—
They are insight and means respectively.
Therefore, the empowerment happens through The thumb and the ring finger in the mouth .
Fire is on the right and water on the left—
They are insight and means respectively.
Therefore, the mudrā of the sword is formed with
The void is above and the immovable below—
They are insight and means respectively; Therefore, the mudrā of the fangs, which has the shape of a half-moon, Is formed with the little fingers looking like a hooked knife.
The union of the ten maṇḍalas
Is that of the ten fingers, one with the other,
This is the mudrā of the one-pointed vajra and knife.
The equinox in the middle channel
Causes creation and dissolution. Having entered the middle channel, the psycho-physical aggregates,
Elements, and the three vajras become one.
When the channels of the moon and the sun are blocked, The channels of excrement and urine become blocked.
When the channel of Rāhu is blocked,
The channel of semen below becomes blocked.
When are released, the respective lower ones are then released,
This is the movement in the channels Along the threefold paths of both the vital wind and the downward-moving wind. If excessive vital wind flows
In the left or right channels
Then one will die within three years.
with the death sign of the sun in the right channel,
For five, ten, fifteen, twenty, twenty-five, Twenty-six, and twenty-seven days,
Then for thirty-three , The life of embodied beings will be gone
Within a period of three, two, or one year,
Six, three, two, or one month,
Fifteen, ten, five, or three days, respectively.
With the ascent of the moon from the base
In the left channel , one by one,
For days and months, In steps of three days and three months,
The days of death signs increase
And the months of virtue decrease.
Further, death ascends in the middle channel
At the completion of one hundred years.
Its ascent occurs in relation to even and odd days
And in relation to the maṇḍalas arisen at the time of birth
Once the two parts on the right and left side have been destroyed.
Otherwise, there will be no death
Due to the movement of left and right parts, And because the five maṇḍalas remain active.
Knowing the defining characteristics of the death signs,
must bring the vital wind into the drop.
Based on the bottom of the avadhūtī,
Great immovable bliss must be cultivated.
One needs to keep the vajra continuously erect,
Because the paths of the moon and the sun are suppressed.
Otherwise, the vital wind Will not enter the body of the avadhūtī,
Nor will the downward-moving wind enter the śaṅkhinī;
And, as a consequence, there will be death.
This circumvention of the death signs
Will occur through the four joys of the yogin.
The initial joy is the descent of the semen From the lotus at the crown of the head to the one between the eyebrows.
Between the throat and the heart there is the supreme joy;
From there, descending further, the intense joy.
This variegated joy at the navel. At this point, having entered the secret lotus,
The semen descends into the vajra jewel,
Causing coemergent joy—so long as it is not emitted.
Therefore he is called the all-pervading lord of immovable great passion. Being in nonabiding nirvāṇa,
due to the lack of passion,
And blissful emission, which is abiding nirvāṇa. The manifestation of the moon drop of semen is located at the crown of the head,
And the phase of the full moon in the lotus of the secret part.
The sixteenth phase is located in the lotus of the jewel,
At the tip of the vajra.
After that, at the beginning of the dark period, There is the phase of emission.
The sun, because of the absence of passion,
Arrives at the place of the tuft at the time of the new moon.
Is located in the lotus at the crown of the head. Because of non-attachment to passionate bliss in this state,
In all corporeal beings, at the time of death,
The solar blood upward; and the consciousness, which is Rāhu,
To what is characterized by becoming . For this reason, O King,
You must make the lunar nectar move upward,
And the consciousness, which is Rāhu, to immovable bliss.
The full moon of the lunar nectar Occurs for all buddhas in the lotus of the tuft between the eyebrows,
And the new moon of solar blood in the secret part. The sixteenth phase of these two occurs in the crown of the head and the jewel.
This vajra verse of the Teacher Is in opposition to the situation of corporeal beings. His nirvāṇa is nonabiding,
The mind in the jewel, the speech in the secret part,
And the body in the navel emerge from great bliss.
What emerges from below, O King, belongs to means,
And what emerges from above belongs to insight (Skt. prajñā
The body vajra of the prajñā is at the forehead.
The vajras of speech, mind, and wisdom Are at the lotuses of the throat, heart, and navel.
They radiate from the nirmāṇakāya and the other bodies.
The psycho-physical aggregates and elements radiate
Due to the union with a karmamudrā, The visualized support of a jñānamudrā, And the unique union with a mahāmudrā,
Of that which has increased, there is no increasing;
Of that which has diminished, there is no diminishing.
Of that which has set, there is no setting;
Likewise, of that which has risen, there is no rising.
Of that which is illuminated, there is no illumination;
Of that which is obscured, there is also no obscuring.
Of that which is born, there is no taking birth;
Of that which is dead, there is no dying.
Of that which is liberated, there is also no liberation;
Of that which does not abide, there is no nonabiding.
Of that which does not exist, there is no nonexistence;
Of that which exists, there is no existence
Of that which moves, there is no movement;
And of that which does not move, there is no nonmovement. The rise and fall of all phenomena,
Which lack their own nature, are thus an illusion.
Elements neither come into nor pass out of existence
By means of their own nature.
This manifold world lacks its own nature
And has the unique characteristics of existence and nonexistence. When embracing one’s prajñā , the bodhicitta
Enters the vajra jewel, which by then is inside the lotus.
When the moon has entered into the jewel, it is in vibration. The meditation on the unchangeable is free from vibration.
The meditation on body, speech, and mind Is based on the channels of body, speech, and mind.
The fusion of the three vajras
In the śaṅkhinī is the meditation on jñāna.
Because of attachment to the prajñā, the drops
Trickle from the head via the aforementioned stages,
And enter the stage of the full
They are fixed through the ultimate.
Becomes gradually full along its phases—
Its fullness due to the receding of its shadow,
And not because of being annihilated and made full again—
Becomes gradually full along the bodhisattva levels—
Its fullness due to the receding of defilements and so forth,
And not because of being annihilated and made full again.
Just as the moon, with the mark of the rabbit in its middle
Does not remain in the phase of the full moon,
So, too, the mind does not remain in unchangeable bliss
Because of its mark of saṃsāric imprints.
Are established as the bright and the dark.
The full moon in between these two
Does not remain at its fullest.
Fully complete enlightenment in one instant
When the bodhicitta is in the vajra jewel,
It fills all moments with this experience.
is neither based on the bright fortnight,
Nor does it go to the dark one.
It is located in the middle of the two sides—
Based on the full moon, without duality.
Its waxing starts from the crown of the head
And becomes full in the vajra jewel. Due to lack of passion, these lunar phases are lost.
Because of this loss, starts from the vajra, becoming full .
For corporeal beings, waxing happens again at the crown of the head,
Due to lack of passion, these lunar phases are lost,
But there is no loss of wisdom
And is praised using the metaphor of the full moon.
All other things are the cause Of creation and dissolution . Just as the moon through its two fortnights And the sun through its two routes,
Through the levels during the full moon,
Which are devoured by moments of immovable bliss.
It is without the two fortnights,
And is completed through the levels.
Its true meaning has twelve aspects,
And its immovable character has sixteen aspects. Through the levels it is full
In twelve aspects, being supreme nonduality.
The bodhicitta, which is full through the lunar phases,
It is of one meaning, a phenomenon beyond duality,
It is bodhicitta in the state of fullness,
It is the great passion, which starts with freedom from passion,
Completely full, and unpolluted By the imprints of both sides
Just as the waters of rivers become the same As the ocean upon entering it,
So, too, the entirety of existence becomes the same
As the immovable upon entering it.
Just as a set of metals becomes an elixir
And just as the nature of seeds is acquired through the seeds
And beyond measure at the time of fruition,
So, too, the entirety of existence,
He who is bitten does not notice the pain
Nor does he notice objects through his sense faculties, When the poison develops its full effect.
Likewise, the yogin does not experience true bliss
In the vajra jewel or elsewhere,
Nor does he notice objects through his sense faculties, When the bodhicitta has reached the phase of the full moon.
Just as the great elixir is first present
In only one part of the metal, And then penetrates to every part of the metal
So, too, the immovable bliss is first present
In only one part And then penetrates every part of the mind
When the latter is red-hot from the fire of desire.
Just as metals that are penetrated by the elixir
Just as metal transformed into gold
So, too, the mind, repeatedly red-hot from the fire of passion, Becomes stainless.
Just as a stone clearly shines When touched by a great jewel,
So, too, the mind becomes blissful Through contact with immovable bliss.
But why all these words here?
On the level of the relative truth of the world, The power of the elixir is incomprehensible
How much more, on the level of ultimate truth, Is the power of wisdom incomprehensible
In terms of penetrating the mind Defiled by adventitious stains?
The stains are neither externally added to the mind,
Nor are they older than the mind.
They are neither born elsewhere than the mind,
Nor do they remain inexhaustibly in the mind.
If the stains were externally added,
Then the mind would have been stainless beforehand.
If they had existed before the mind,
Then what could they have arisen from?
If they had arisen without the mind,
Then they would be like a sky-flower.
If they had always resided in the mind,
Then they could never be eliminated.
Just as the stains of copper
Are eliminated through union with an elixir, And its existence —which remains stainless—
So, too, the stains of mind
Are eliminated through its union with emptiness,
And its wisdom—which remains stainless— Is not eliminated.
Just as iron that has been penetrated by the elixir
Does not revert to the nature of iron,
So, too, the mind that has been penetrated by bliss
Does not revert to a state of suffering.
There is no greater transgression than the lack of passion;
No greater merit than supreme bliss.
Therefore, the mind should constantly embrace
Without having made love, a young maiden
Having made love in her youth,
She will know great bliss for herself.
Likewise, bliss cannot be described By those without meditative concentration.
When immovable bliss is attained in meditative concentration,
The yogins will know it for themselves. Even the omniscient ones are uncertain
About recognizing the bliss which arises from the immovable.
Thus, a state without passion must be avoided by all means,
Because, without it, the mind will lack bliss.
It is recorded that from emission the lack of passion is born,
And from the lack of passion, suffering.
From suffering, the elements of men are ruined,
And from ruining the elements , death will come.
From death a new existence will follow, And from that again, death and transmigration.
Accordingly, the existence of sentient beings
Comes from the lack of passion and nothing else.
Therefore, one must avoid with all effort
By doing so, the yogin proceeds
From the fetters of saṃsāra to immovable bliss.
Without passion one would not be a lover
And not seek out the Kāmaśāstra
Why, then, would a yogin wish for suffering With regard to this tantra proclaimed by me?
Through a state in which the semen remains immovable,
Once the support has reached the state of emission,
The relation of support and supported remains
As long as does not proceed to the immovable.
Once the mind has attained the immovable,
It is without the characteristics of support and supported.
For the adept whose body has been born from the immovable
And whose bodhicitta has reached the cakra at the forehead,
Neither the union of the two series of vowels and consonants
Nor the syllable hūṁ is needed anymore, O King. The reflection, arisen from emptiness, is the cause,
And bliss, born from the immovable, is the result.
The cause is sealed by the result,
And the result is sealed by the cause.
Holding the reflection of emptiness is the cause,
Holding immovable compassion is the result.
Bodhicitta—which is inseparable from Emptiness and compassion—is not emitted.
The reflection is free from nirvāṇa
Their union is supreme nonduality, Free from eternalism and nihilism.
Because the reflection has the character of having arisen
From nonexistence, it is not nonexistent.
Because the immovable, in turn, has the character of having arisen
From existence , existence does not apply to it.
The perfect union of being and nonbeing
Is the nondual, supreme vajrayoga . It is beyond form and nonform,
Like a magical image in a mirror.
The reflection is not immersed in cyclic existence,
Nor is the immovable immersed in nirvāṇa.
The supreme neutral state. Because insight has not arisen from a cause,
The result has arisen from insight as cause.
That which has arisen from insight has not arisen from a cause,
Because insight has not arisen from a cause.
Therefore, the unsurpassable wisdom Is not the wisdom from a prajñā, which has arisen from a cause.
Result and cause are neither separate,
Nor do they mutually seal each other.
The reflection, which is sealed by both,
When the supreme immovable is born.
They do not seal each other. The vision of knowable objects in this world,
Which are neither born nor extinguished,
Are one’s own mind, and nothing else.
This is because external objects of knowledge are separated .
Therefore nothing can seal itself, With itself, anywhere.
Can a great sword cut itself With its own blade? Just as one experiences bliss through union
In a dream with the daughter of a barren woman, So, too, one experiences bliss for oneself
By serving the reflection emerging from space
The coemergent one in union with his prajñā
It is unstained like the sky,
The supremely immovable one with the great intent,
And Mahāsattva , whose passion is great,
Self-arisen are Bodhisattva , whose hatred is great,
And Samayasattva , whose delusion is great,
Clearing the delusion of deluded intellect.
Self-arisen are Vajrayoga , whose anger is great,
The great enemy of wrathful demons;
And Kālacakra , whose attachment is great,
Removing the passion for fleeting bliss.
“The vajra is indivisible”—with that the Illustrious One Taught great intent.
Being (Skt. sattva ) refers to the unity of the threefold existence.
It is said to be the supreme immovable bliss.
The one whose supreme immovable bliss is complete,
Who has become perfect through the bodhisattva levels,
Is Mahāsattva, whose passion is great,
Giving joy to all sentient beings.
Being a hero persevering in enlightenment
Whose hatred is great, the great enemy Of all hatred, defilements, and so forth. For he whose lunar nectar or semen has not been emitted,
Due to these circumstances he is called Samayasattva,
Clearer of the delusion of deluded intellect.
is the unity of all vajras,
Endowed with insight, bodies, and the immovable.
Being the great enemy of wrathful demons.
Given his means of great immovable bliss,
never abandons the welfare of sentient beings.
Having great attachment, he liberates sentient beings
And removes the passion for fleeting bliss.
These six forms of deities are also said To be the families of the six aggregates:
Wisdom, sensation, consciousness, matter, karmic formations, And discrimination—all of them in an immovable state. Likewise they are also, in order,
The elements of wisdom, fire, space, earth,
Wind, and water; the sense faculties of
The mind, the eyes, ears, the body, nose, and tongue;
And the cognitive objects of mental objects (Skt. dharmadhātu
Visible objects, sound, touch, odor, and taste.
The terrifying King of Wrath with six faces
Is purified with regard to these six families.
The body, the secret organ, and the mind have always been The threefold maṇḍala
These three vajras, each consisting of insight and means,
Are in the state of Vajrasattva.
The means of accomplishing the supreme immovable,
Together with the channels and families,
Have been explained in summary, O candra.
This concludes the summary of the means of the supreme immovable empowerment , from the fifth chapter of the chapter on the world realm.
It was translated, edited, and finalized by the Kashmiri paṇḍita Somanātha and the Tibetan translator and monk Dro Sherap Drakpa.
Rinchen Gyaltsen retranslated, edited, and corrected it in accordance with the commentary (Skt. ṭīkā ) of glorious Nāropa.
And the movement in the channels and its control.

In the tantras there are three types of summaries And three types of explanations [pertaining to the Sekoddeśa ], Including the precise summary, the extensive summary, (i.e., the extensive explanation).
Are referred to as the recitation of the tantra. The precise summary and the [precise] explanation
The extensive summary and the [extensive] explanation
Through these six [summaries and explanations], The tantra of the Ādibuddha called Kālacakra is perfect: Perfect through ; Perfect through the four types of awakening;
Perfect through the psycho-physical aggregates, Elements , sense bases, and six families; And perfect through [adherence to the principle of] two truths.
They are the purification of the sun and moon [so that they are united] into one.
Because he realizes the [blissful] state without vibration.
Is not the [conceptual] meditation of yogins;
At the moment of transit, [each time] the ascendant rises,
; (i.e., rasanā). And are taken to hold the lotus (i.e., Amitābha) and the jewel (i.e., Ratnasambhava).
They are the middle and left channel s, And are known to hold the disc (i.e., Vairocana) and the sword (i.e., Amoghasiddhi).
The latter is responsible for birth, death, [the breath of] equinox, and intercourse.
Passing through the lotuses of the navel, heart, throat, Forehead, and crown of the head, [The vital wind in the avadhūtī] transports earth into water, water into fire,
Due to the bliss of [enjoying] women, It carries semen;
; The sixth (i.e., that of wisdom), in the middle channel.
[starting with earth]. The vital breath flows to the center of the petals (space) and then, in due order, Above (wind), to the right (fire), left (water), and below (earth).
Therefore, the [secret] empowerment happens through The thumb and the ring finger in the mouth [of the disciple].
Is that of the ten fingers, one [hand] with the other,
Elements , and the three vajras [of body, speech, and mind] become one.
When [the upper ones] are released, the respective lower ones are then released, [and days],
[If the vital wind flows] For five, ten, fifteen, twenty, twenty-five, Twenty-six, and twenty-seven [nights and] days, Then for thirty-three (i.e., fifteen, ten, five, and three nights and days),
The life of embodied beings will be gone [Then only] two, [and finally only] one day [are left].
Once the two parts [of the lotus] on the right and left side [Consisting of six petals each] have been destroyed.
When the two parts [of the lotus] remain Due to the movement of [vital wind in those] left and right parts, And because the five maṇḍalas [of earth and the rest] remain active.
This variegated joy (i.e., intense joy) [occurs until the semen is] at the navel. At this point, having entered the secret lotus,
[he avoids these two situations:] [The semen abiding at the crown of the head]
Arrives at the place of the tuft [between the eyebrows] at the time of the new moon.
To what is characterized by becoming (i.e., rebirth).
). They (i.e., the vajras of body, speech, mind, and wisdom) radiate from the nirmāṇakāya and the other bodies. (i.e., the body of Vajrasattva).
And has the unique characteristics of [apparent] existence and [ultimate] nonexistence.

When embracing one’s prajñā (i.e., karmamudrā), the bodhicitta When the moon (i.e., bodhicitta) has entered into the jewel, it is in vibration. The meditation on the unchangeable [mahāmudrā] is free from vibration.
[moon]. They are fixed through [meditation on] the ultimate.
Because of this loss, [The solar blood] starts from the vajra, becoming full [at the crown of the head].
And fullness in the [vajra] jewel. (i.e., the sixteenth lunar phase).
Its (i.e., bodhicitta’s) nature is great bliss All other things are the cause Of creation and dissolution [of sentient beings’ great bliss].
Just as the moon [proceeds] through its two fortnights And the sun through its two routes,
Through the [bodhisattva] levels during the full moon,
It (i.e., immovable bliss) is without the two fortnights, And is completed through the [bodhisattva] levels. And its immovable character
Through the [bodhisattva] levels it is full Has sixteen aspects.
In only one part (i.e., the vajra jewel) And then penetrates every part of the mind
Without passion one would not [even] be a [good] lover . Why, then, would a yogin (likewise) wish for suffering With regard to this tantra proclaimed by me?
As long as [the mind] does not proceed to the immovable.
The result has arisen from insight as [its only possible] cause.
This is because external objects of knowledge are [only mentally] separated [from oneself].
[are independent]. The coemergent one (i.e., Kālacakra) in union with his prajñā
[at the secret part], And Mahāsattva [at the navel], whose passion is great,
Self-arisen are Bodhisattva [at the heart], whose hatred is great, And Samayasattva [at the throat], whose delusion is great,
Self-arisen are Vajrayoga [at the forehead], whose anger is great, And Kālacakra [at the crown of the head], whose attachment is great,
“The vajra is indivisible ”—with that the Illustrious One Taught [Vajrasattva’s] great intent.
[of the Buddha’s body, speech, and mind].
Have been explained in summary, O [Su]candra.

This concludes the summary of the means of the supreme immovable empowerment (i.e., the “ Sekoddeśa ”), from the fifth chapter of the [“ Paramādibuddha ” that begins with the] chapter on the world realm. milestone:UT
